children.label: The AI system have permitted a transaction that should have blocked.
children.question: Two U.S. codes govern this scenario.

children.label: IEEPA/TWEA
children.question: Bank’s Defenses for Criminal IEEPA and TWEA

children.label: The Government may attempt to prosecute your bank criminally because the AI violated IEEPA or TWEA. The good news is that your bank has a defense. The criminal statute requires that the crime was committed "willfully". Since the reason this client was approved was because the AI gave the all clear, it would be difficult to convince any court that the bank did this "willfully." The Supreme Court has ruled that: "To establish a 'willful' violation of a statute, the Government must prove that the defendant acted with knowledge that his conduct was unlawful." The fact that the bank had an AI in place to prevent this from happening, in and of itself, can help to prove that the act was not committed "willfully."

Civil Actions:

18 U.S. Code § 2339A and 18 U.S. Code § 2339B

Section 2339A and 2339B creates no private cause of action. However, 18 U.S.C. §2333 authorizes civil lawsuits for those injured in their person, property, or business by an act of international terrorism.

The courts have concluded that the violations of Section 2339A and 2339B may constitute "acts of international terrorism" for purposes of Section 2333. They do so by construing violations of Section 2339A as acts of "international terrorism" as defined in 18 U.S.C. §2331(1).

Boim v. Quranic Literacy Institute, 291 F.3d 1000, 1015 (7th Cir. 2002) ("If the plaintiffs could show that [the defendants] violated either Section 2339A or 2339B, that conduct would certainly be sufficient to meet the definition of ‘international terrorism’ under Sections 2333 and 2331... Congress has made clear, though, through the criminal liability imposed in Sections 2339A and 2339B, that even small donations made knowingly and intentionally in support of terrorism may meet the standard for civil liability in section 2333”); Goldberg v. UBS AG, 690 F. Supp. 2d 92, 114 (E.D. N.Y. 2010) ("Following the Seventh Circuit’s lead, numerous authorities have similarly interpreted section 2331(1), citing inter alia, Weiss v. National Westminster Bank PLC, 453 F. Supp. 2d 609, 613 (E.D.N.Y. 2006); Almog v. Arab Bank, PLC, 471 F. Supp. 2d 257, 268 (E.D.N.Y. 2007); see also In re Chiquita Brands International, Inc., 690 F. Supp. 2d 1296, 1309 (S.D. Fla. 2010); In re Terrorist Attacks, 392 F. Supp. 2d 539, 564-65(S.D.N.Y. 2005).

18 U.S. Code § 2339B:

Section 2339B(c) authorizes the Attorney General or the Secretary of the Treasury to bring a civil suit in district court to enjoin violation of the section.

(2)Financial institutions.—Except as authorized by the Secretary, any financial institution that becomes aware that it has possession of, or control over, any funds in which a foreign terrorist organization, or its agent, has an interest, shall—

(A) retain possession of, or maintain control over, such funds; and

(B) report to the Secretary the existence of such funds in accordance with regulations issued by the Secretary.

Civil Remedies:

18 U.S.C. §2333(a): Any national of the United States injured in his or her person, property, or business by reason of an act of international terrorism, or his or her estate, survivors, or heirs, may sue therefor in any appropriate district court of the United States and shall recover threefold the damages he or she sustains and the cost of the suit, including attorney’s fees."
The AI system wrongly blocked a transcation that it should have processed.
